data.title: Famous people who attended Alabama colleges
data.meta_description: How many of these former students did you know?
data.text:
From entertainers and authors, to groundbreaking female sports figures, we've listed former students at Alabama colleges who went on to do big things. Test your knowledge: How many did you know?

AL.com File Photo

Last week, I posted separate lists of famous former students from Auburn and the University of Alabama. Don't miss them.

Read: 30 famous people who attended the University of Alabama

Read: 30 famous people who attended Auburn University.

Note: None of the lists are meant to be all-inclusive.

AL.com File Photo

Rudy Abbott, born December 29, 1940, in Anniston. College baseball coach who led the Jacksonville State Gamecocks to two national championships. Played for the Gamecocks while attending Jacksonville State University.

Wikimedia Commons

Mary Anderson (April 2, 1918-April 6, 2014) born in Birmingham. Actor, known for portraying Maybelle Merriweather in "Gone With the Wind." Attended Howard College, now called Samford University.

AL.com File Photo

Lucille Benson (July 17, 1914-February 17, 1984) born in Scottsboro, Alabama. Actress known for roles in "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," and TV's "Bosom Buddies." Attended Huntingdon College.

Bob Carlton/bcarlton@al.com

Rick Bragg, born July 26, 1959, in Piedmont. Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author of non-fiction books. Attended Jacksonville State University.

AL.com File Photos

Bill "Bubba" Bussey, left, (born March 27, 1964, in Montgomery) and Rick Burgess (born October 3, 1964, in Birmingham), hosts of the nationally syndicated "Rick and Bubba Show" on talk radio. Attended Jacksonville State University.

AL.com File Photo

Pat Buttram (June 19-1915-January 8, 1994), born in Addison, Alabama. Actor, known for his portrayal of Mr. Haney on "Green Acres." Attended Birmingham-Southern College.

AL.com File Photo/Mark Almond

Clarence Carter, born January 14, 1936, in Montgomery, Alabama. Blues and soul singer, musician, songwriter, record producer. Attended Alabama State University.

Brian J Myers at Photo Run/AL.com

Jearl Miles Clark, born September 4, 1966, in Gainesville, Florida. Track and field athlete; won gold medals in the 4-by-400 relay in the 1996 and 2000 Olympic games. Attended Alabama A&M University.

AL.com File Photo

Mary Elizabeth Counselman (November 19-1911-November 13, 1995) born in Birmingham. Wrote science fiction stories for books and magazines. She attended the University of Alabama and Montevallo.

AL.com File Photo

Clifton Davis, born October 4, 1945, in Chicago, Illinois. Actor on shows like "Amen," songwriter for hits for the Jackson 5, and pastor. Attended Oakwood University.

AL.com File Photo

Jennifer Pharr Davis, born May 25, 1983, in Hendersonville, North Carolina. World-record holder, fastest through hike of the Appalachian Trial, 2011. Attended Samford University.

AL.com File Photo

Bobby Jon Drinkard, born May 10, 1977, in Troy. Actor, model, contestant on the "Survivor" reality series. Graduated from Troy University.

Damon Winter/Dallas Morning News/AL.com File

Vonetta Flowers, born October 29, 1973, in Helena, Alabama. Olympic bobsledder who won gold in the 2002 games. Attended the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

AL.com File Photo

Jim Folsom Jr. born May 14, 1949, in Montgomery. Served as 50th governor of Alabama. Attended Jacksonville State University.

1st Lt. Jermaine Thurston/Army

Kayla Freeman of Huntsville, a second lieutenant, became the first black female pilot in the National Guard in 2018. She graduated from Tuskegee University.

AL.com File Photo

Elizabeth Futral, born September 27, 1963, in Johnston County, North Carolina. International opera star, a coloratura soprano. Attended Samford University.

AL.com File Photo

Anne George (December 4, 1927-March 14, 2001) born in Montgomery. Pulitzer Prize-nominated poet and Agatha Award-winning mystery novelist, known for the Southern Sisters series. Attended Samford University.

AL.com File Photo

Thom Gossom Jr., born 1952 in Birmingham. Actor on TV shows such as "In the Heat of the Night" and films such as "Jeepers Creepers 2." Gossom, a wide receiver, became the first black student-athlete to graduate from Auburn. He also attended the University of Montevallo.

Read about more famous people who attended Auburn University by clicking here.

AL.com File Photo

Cary Guffey, born May 10, 1972, in Douglasville, Georgia. Child actor known for portraying the little boy in "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." Attended Jacksonville State University.

RB Chesterton/Wikimedia Commons

Carolyn Haines, born May 12, 1953 in Hattiesburg, Mississippi. Mystery writer. Attended University of South Alabama.

AL.com File Photo

James Haskins (September 19, 1941-July 6, 2005) born in Demopolis, Alabama. Award-winning author of books for children and adults, on subjects from Hank Aaron to Malcolm X. Attended Alabama State University.

Grammy.com

Chuck Harmony, born Charles Harmon in 1979 in East St. Louis, Illinois. Music, producer, musician, songwriter. Attended Alabama State University.

AL.com File Photo

Erskine Hawkins (July 26, 1914-November 11, 1993) born in Birmingham. Trumpeter and big band leader known for composing "Tuxedo Junction." Attended Alabama State University.

Wikimedia Commons

Kurt Heinecke, born in Wisconsin and raised in Cullman, and Tim Hodge, born April 2, 1963, in Boaz, Alabama. Helped create the popular animated children's series "Veggie Tales" for Big Idea Entertainment. Attended University of Montevallo.

Warren Linhart/AL.com

Patterson Hood, born March 24, 1964, in Muscle Shoals. Singer, co-founder of the band Drive-By Truckers. Attended the University of North Alabama.

AL.com File Photo

Michael Conner Humphreys, born March 1, 1985, in Independence, Missouri. Actor known for playing young Forrest Gump in "Forrest Gump." Later joined the Army. Attended the University of North Alabama.

Scott Dudleson/Getty Images/AL.com

Sam Hunt, born December 8, 1984, in Cedartown, Georgia. Country music singer and songwriter. Attended the University of Alabama at Birmingham, where he played quarterback on the football team.

AL.com File Photo

Lonnie Johnson, born October 6, 1949, in Mobile. Engineer and inventor of the Super Soaker water gun. Attended Tuskegee University.

Strauss/Invision/AP File Photos

Karen Fairchild Jordan, left, and Kimberly Schlapman of Homewood. Founding members of the country group Little Big Town. Attended Samford University.

AL.com File Photo

Michael Kearney, born January 18, 1984, in Hawaii. World's Youngest College Graduate certified by Guinness World Records, graduated from the University of South Alabama at age 10.

AP File Photo

Harper Lee (April 28, 1926- February 19, 2016), born in Monroeville. Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "To Kill a Mockingbird." She attended Huntingdon College and briefly attended the University of Alabama.

Read about more famous graduates of the University of Alabama by clicking here.

AL.com File Photo

George Lindsey (December 17, 1928-May 6, 2012) born in Fairfield, Alabama. Actor known for portraying Goober Pyle on "The Andy Griffith Show" and on "Hee-Haw." Attended University of North Alabama, where he played football.

AL.com File Photo

Little Richard, born Richard Wayne Penniman, December 5, 1932, in Macon Georgia. Singer and songwriter known for hits like "Good Golly, Miss Molly." Attended Oakwood University.

Newhouse/AL.com File Photo

Rebecca Luker, born April 17, 1961, in Helena, Alabama. Broadway actress known for roles in "The Phantom of the Opera" and "The Sound of Music," among others. Attended the University of Montevallo.

AL.com File Photo

Sunny Mabrey, born November 28, 1975, in Gadsden. Actress and model known for portraying Glinda the Good Witch in the TV series "Once Upon a Time," and roles in films like "The New Guy" and "XXX: State of the Union." Attended the University of Mobile.

Dave Martin/AP File Photo

Ashley Martin, born 1981 in Georgia. Football kicker. First woman to play and score in an NCAA Division I. Played at Jacksonville State University.

AL.com File Photo

Hugh Martin (August 11, 1914-March 11, 2011), born in Birmingham. Music composer for films and theater, perhaps best known for writing "Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas" for the movie "Meet Me in St. Louis." Attended Birmingham-Southern College.

Taylor Hill/Emmis Digital

Miles Parks McCollum, aka Lil Yachty, born August 23, 1997, in Marbleton, Georgia. Rapper known for "One Night" and "Minnesota." Attended Alabama State University.

AL.com File Photo

Sena Jeter Naslund, born June 28, 1942, in Birmingham. Author of novels including "Four Spirits" and writer-in-residence at the University of St. Louis. She graduated from Birmingham-Southern College.

Michael Nichols, National Geographic Creative

Michael "Nick" Nichols, born 1952 in Muscle Shoals. Renowned photojournalist and wildlife photographer for National Geographic. Attended the University of North Alabama, where he met his mentor, LIFE magazine photographer Charles Moore, according to Nichols' online biography. His life is the subject of "A Wild Life: A Visual Biography of Photographer Michael Nichols," by Melissa Harris.

AL.com File Photo

Randy Owen, born December 13, 1949, in Fort Payne, Alabama. Cofounder and lead singer of the country music group Alabama, which has produced more than 20 gold and platinum records. Graduated from Jacksonville State University.

Washington Post photo by Marvin Joseph

Lionel Richie, born June 20, 1949, in Tuskegee. Grammy Award-winning singer; attended Tuskegee University and briefly attended classes at Auburn University.

AL.com File Photo

Glenn Shadix (April 15, 1952-September 7, 2010) born in Bessemer, Alabama. Actor know for roles in films such as "Beetlejuice" and "Heathers." Attended the University of North Alabama and Birmingham-Southern College.

Collette Smith/LinkedIn

Collette V. Smith of New York, a former women's football player, is the first female African American coach in the National Football League. She coaches for the New York Jets. She attended Tuskegee University.

Tuskegee.edu

Danielle Spencer, born June 24, 1965, in Trenton, N.J. Child actress, known for playing Dee on "What's Happening!" now a veterinarian. Attended Tuskegee University.

Eric Schultz/AL.com

John Stallworth, born July 15, 1952, in Tuscaloosa. Wide receiver in the National Football League who went to four Super Bowls. He graduated from Alabama A&M University.

Davenport Design Studio/AL.com

Ruben Studdard, born September 12, 1978, in Birmingham. R&B, pop and gospel singer, winner of "American Idol." He attended Alabama A&M University.

Everett Collection/AL.com

Sun Ra, born Herman Poole Blount May 22, 1914, in Birmingham. Jazz composer and poet known for experimental music. He attended Alabama A&M University.

Birmingham Public Library

Ellen Tarry (September 26, 1906-September 23, 2008) born in Birmingham. First African American picture book author. Attended Alabama State University. In this 1950 photo, Tarry, far left against book case, reads to children at the Booker T. Washington Branch Library.

AP File Photo/Gail Burton

Sarah Thomas, born 1973 in Pascagoula, Mississippi. First female to referee Division 1 FBS NCAA football game and first permanent NFL official. Graduated from the University of Mobile, where she played basketball.

AP Photo/Jon Way

Keenen Ivory Wayans, born June 8, 1958, in New York. Actor, comedian, film maker; attended Tuskegee University.

Jerry Ayers/AL.com

Heather Whitestone, born February 24, 1973, in Dothan. First handicapped Miss America. Graduated from Jacksonville State University.

Doug Ferguson/Associated Press

Danny Willett, born October 3, 1987, in England. Pro golfer, winner of the Masters. Played two seasons on the Jacksonville State University golf team.

AL.com File Photo
